comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The Tlalpan Cadets were the personal guard of Mexican President Huerta.

comment.author: 25252126@N08
comment._content: Christmas Glitter Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year!! Well done, Keep up the good work!

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: In the Getty Research Institute Digital Collections there's a photo entitled Arcos de Belén, Aspirantes (cadets) de Tlalpan. archives.getty.edu/R/EX9QIQGC4X2NJ2L4HKVSBKN47HUUMG3NREND... taken most likely during the Decena Trágica (Ten Tragic Days), between February 9 to 18, 1913. The cadets seem to wear the same uniforms, so both pictures could be a part of a series. And if they were Huerta's personal guard, they were approaching National Palace when President Madero was already arrested or murdered on February 22nd? Or they are approaching Palace when they assaulted it in the evening of February 9th? Think is the most likely date, before the battle of that day. Seminario Street runs north to south and the corner building is at Moneda Street which runs east to west. Across that street just behind the camera is National Palace. Dr. Roberto Duarte Plastic Surgeon

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: Found in Wikipedia En la madrugada del 9 de febrero de 1913 se inició una sublevación en la Ciudad de México con la intención de derrocar al presidente Francisco I. Madero. Los generales Manuel Mondragón, Félix Díaz (it seems to be most likely the officer riding on the black-faced horse in the foreground) y Bernardo Reyes, apoyados por los cadetes de la Escuela Militar de Aspirantes de Tlalpan y la tropa del cuartel de Tacubaya, tomaron por asalto el Palacio Nacional. El sitio fue rescatado por el general Lauro Villar. Durante la refriega murieron casi un centenar de civiles y soldados, entre ellos el general Bernardo Reyes. Los rebeldes, a pesar de contar con superioridad numérica, decidieron retirarse para refugiarse en La Ciudadela.1 This is to differentiate from the Heróico Colegio Militar Cadets who supported Madero Se conoce como la Marcha de la Lealtad al recorrido que realizó el presidente mexicano Francisco I. Madero, el 9 de febrero de 1913, del Castillo de Chapultepec al Palacio Nacional escoltado por los cadetes del Heroico Colegio Militar durante el inicio del golpe de Estado conocido como Decena Trágica. es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcha_de_la_Lealtad
